One evening I sat
in my
chemic
workshop,
the sun had
set
& the moon
was just rising from the
sea —
I had not
light sufficient
for my
work employment
and I
sat
idle mus untill
in
the
^
a
pause of consideration
of whether I should leave my labour for
the
night
or hasten its conclusion by an
unremitting attention to it. As I
sat
a train
of reflection
occur e r ed
to
me
which led
to me
consider the effects of what I was now
doing.
Two
^
three
years before I
had been
engaged
in the same
manner
& had created a
fiend whose
unparralelled
barbarity had
desolated my
heart
and filled it
for
ever
with the bitterest remorse. I was
now about to form another
being
of whose
dispositions I was alike
ignorant.
She
might
be
ten thousand times more ma
lignant than her
mate
and
delight
in
murder & wretchedness. He had sworn
to quit the neighbourhood of
man
& hide
himself in
desarts
but she had
not &
she
who
was in all probability
to become
a thinking & reasoning
animal
might
refuse to
to comply with a compact made
before her creation. They might even
hate
one another.
The creature who al
ready lived loathed his own
deformity
& might he not conceive a greater ab
horrence for it when it came before
his eyes in the female
form.
She also
might turn with disgust from him
to the superior beauty of
man & who
confine her eyes or wishes .
She might
quit
him
and he be again
alone with
^
exasperated by
the fresh provocation of being deserted
by one of his own species.
Even if they were to leave
Europe
& inhabit the
desarts
of the new world,
I it was their intention to have children
and a race of devils would be propagated
up on the earth from whose form & mind
man shrunk with horro w r . &
had I
any right
for
for my own
benefit
to inflict this
curse
to
everlasting generations? I had
before been moved by the sophisms
of the being
whom I had created; I had
been
moved
by his fiendish
threats & now
for the first
time
the wickedness
& utter
selfishness
selfishness
of my promise burst
upo m n
me;
I
shud d ered
to think that future ages might
curse me as their
pest whose
had not hesitated to buy its own peace at
the
price perhaps
of the
^
existence of
whole human
race.
I trembled, and my heart failed
wh
within
me, when
on looking
up
I
saw
by the light of the moon, the dæmon
with at the
' window
casement.

on his countena wrinkled

as he gazed on
me as
where I

followed me in my travels; he had loitered

view

progress

the

ment
of
_________ my promise;
as I looked on
hi s m
his
face countenance
appeared to express ed
the utmost extent of malice
&
barbarity : treachery.
I thought with a sensation
of
horror madness
of on
my promise of crea
ting another like to
him
&
trembling
with
passion as
tore to pieces the thing
on which I was
engaged –
The wretch

with a howl of devi
lish despair
^
&
revenge

I left the
room &
locking the

made a
vow in my own heart never

then
with trem
bling
steps

appartment
I
a was
alone. n
None were near me to
dissipate the

the most terrible reveries.
Several
hours
passed

It was almost
motionless
for the winds were
hushed &
all
nature reposed under the eye of the
quiet
moon
A few fishing
s vessels alone

d wa s f ted

the

^

I felt the

although I was hardly
conscious of
^
its
extreme
profundity untill

In a few minutes
after
I heard the
creaking of my
door
as if some one

presentiment of who it
was
and wished

But
I was overcome by the
fright sensation
of
helplessness
so often felt in
a fright
ful
dream
when you in vain endea
vour to fly
the
impending
danger &

Presently I heard
the sound of footsteps along the
passage,
my
the door
opened

dreaded appeared. Shutting the
door
he
advanced towards
approached
me
&
said
in a
smothered
v voice:— You
have
des
-troyed
the work
that
you
began . ;
What
is it that you intend?
Do you dare
break
your promise? I
h have endured toil

I crept along the shores of the
Rhine
with you ,
among its willow
ils islands

upon over

dured incalculable

&
cold

hunger &
do you dare destroy
m e y hopes?

I do break my
p

Slave, said the wretch,
I before
reasoned with

but you have proved

condescen t s ion.
Remem
ber that I have power; you believe your
self
miserable

Wretch, said I, the
hour of my
weak
ness
is
past
& the period of your power is

resolution

companion
in vice. Shall
I
in
cold blood

Begone,
I am
firm
and your words will

The Monster saw my determination
in my
face

Shall
each
man,

he,
find
his
equal,
& each beast have
his
mate I
and I be
alone.
I had feelings
of

detes
tation. Man you may hate,

Your hours will pass in dread &

will
ravish from you your happiness for ever.
Are you to
^
be
happy

wretchedness.
You
destroy
^
can blast
my
other

dearer than light or

I may
die
but
first
you
my tyrant &
tormentor
shall
curse the sun that gazes on your misery.
Beware,
for I am
fearless
& therefore
powerful. I will watch with the wiliness
of a
snank snake
that I may sting with

inflict.
Devil, I cried, Cease,
& do not
poison the air with
those
sounds
of malice. I have declared my resolution
to
you
and I am no coward to bend
beneath
words –
Leave
me,
I am
inexo
rable.
It
is
well, said he,
I go; but
remem
ber!
I shall be with you on your
marriage night.
Chapter 13
I started
forward
&
exclaimed—Villain,
before
you sign my death-warrant, be sure that
you are yourself
safe.
I would have seized
him
but he eluded
me
and
quitting
the house
with
precipitation
in a few moments I saw him
in his
boat

an arrowy
swiftness
& was soon lost amidst the
waves.
All was again silent; but his words rung in
my
ears;
I
burnt
with rage to pursue the
murderer of my
peace
& precipitate him into
the ocean. I walked up & down my room hastily
& perturbed,
my imagination conjured before
me
a thousand images
all to torment & sting
me –
Why
d had I not followed
him
& closed with
him in
t mortal
strife– ?
But I had suffered
him to
depart

land;
I shuddered to
sup
pose
who might be the next victim sacri
ficed to his insatiate
revenge –
And then
again I thought
of his
words – " I
will be with
you on your
marriage night
That then
was the period fixed for the
fulfillment
of my
destiny – o I n
that
^
hour
I should
die

Yet
when I thought of Elizabeth The prospect did

fear
yet when I thought

Elizabeth; of
her tears & endless

fin e d

The night passed
away

My feelings became
calmer

calmness

of the last
nights contention

that mi such

I
^

barren
rock
wearily

^

myself a sa

When it became
noon

I lay down

grass

composure —Yet

y ears like a

become

g join him. He said

Perth in a week from that

Yet

think
reflect:
I must pack
my chemical

next
morning

sufficient

The remains of the
half fi
nished creature

& I almost felt as

I conveyed the instruments out of the

the
relicks

basket

in the mean time I sat
on
the
beach
em

Nothing
w could be more complete than

pearance of the dæmon. I had before

gloomy despair
as a
n thing

with whatever

eyes
& that
I now
for the first
time
saw clearly.
It never once The idea of

an
instant occur to

The threat I had
heard weighed on my
thoughts
but I
never did
not reflect
suppose d that a voluntary act of mine

avert it. I had resolved in my
own
mind
that to create another like

and I
did not banished

Between two & three in the morning

rose

then
putting my
basket
into
a little
skiff

The scene

solitary,
a few boats were
returning towards
land

about the commission of a dreadful

At one time the

clear

covered
overspread by a thick
cloud
&
^
I

I listened to the gurg
ling sound as it

^

^

s

^

ed it

driv driven into

Fiend,

der
